content:
in deel 2 gaan spreken we met Bram en Marieke over hun ontvoering door de staat en de vrijlating met het zwaard van damocles boven het hoofd. Zij hebben de recente zitting tegen hun medeverdachten bijgewoond als bezoeker, wat al aangeeft dat het OM hen niet nuttig acht om het verhaal omtrent een terroristische organisatie kracht bij te zetten. In de maanden na hun arrestatie hebben ze het leven weer een beetje opgepakt, wel is de impact enorm geweest, emotioneel, sociaal en economisch. Omdat het iedereen kan overkomen in het huidige Nederland delen zij hun verhaal, om licht te schijnen op staatsmisdrijven.

Bekijk het tweede deel: https://youtu.be/zrXp7KBlviw?si=XgbLYKtTg7hLC1xs
content_english:
In part 2 we talk to Bram and Marieke about their kidnapping by the state and their release with the sword of Damocles hanging over their heads. They attended the recent hearing against their co-suspects as visitors, which already indicates that the Public Prosecution Service does not consider them useful to strengthen the story about a terrorist organization. In the months after their arrest, they have resumed life a little, but the impact has been enormous, emotionally, socially and economically. Because it can happen to anyone in today's Netherlands, they share their story to shed light on state crimes.

Watch the second part: https://youtu.be/zrXp7KBlviw?si=XgbLYKtTg7hLC1xs

content:
üáµüá±üá∑üá∫So, Poland is going to demand from Russia and Belarus to "hand over Ukrainian saboteurs" whom they suspect of blowing up the railway tracks that supply Ukraine.

I don't even know how to comment on this.

üáµüá±Poland will raise the terrorist threat level on the railway, Tusk announced in the Polish Sejm

After two terrorist attacks on the railway, the threat level was "Bravo," but with the appearance of Ukrainian saboteurs, the authorities decided to raise it to "Charlie."

üåêüá∫üá¶üá∑üá∫NATO countries want to reduce the time to redeploy troops across Europe to the Russian border by 15 times, the FT newspaper reported.

They plan to deliver equipment and troops from the western to the eastern flank in three days instead of 45.

Currently, according to their data, the infrastructure does not meet the requirements.

üáµüá±üá∑üá∫The Polish Minister of Defense accused Russia of sabotaging the railway, although the suspects have not yet been detained, reports Notes from Poland.

"Only when the criminals are caught will we have absolute certainty, but analyzing all the events happening in Poland and Europe, all traces lead east, to Russia. This is part of the war they are waging against NATO, against Europe, against us ‚Äî a hybrid war, a war meant to sow disorder and fear. It is a strategy to weaken the West," said Kosiniak-Kamysz.

üáµüá±The Polish Prosecutor's Office has launched an investigation into acts of sabotage on railway line number 7, describing them as "terrorist sabotage carried out on behalf of foreign intelligence," according to the agency's website.

üá≠üá∫üá™üá∫üá∫üá¶Calls by European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen to send more money to Ukraine amid corruption scandals are like trying to cure an alcoholic by giving him another case of vodka, said Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orb√°n.
üåêüá∫üá¶üá∑üá∫The NATO Secretary General stated that the EU must provide Ukraine with support, and the source of the funds is not important to him

Ukraine's current medical doctrine, based on methods used by the US and its allies to handle casualties in Iraq and Afghanistan, does not correspond to the nature of this war of attrition.

"When the full-scale Russian invasion occurred in 2022, all American recommendations for Tactical Combat Casualty Care (TCCC) were translated into Ukrainian. But they were written for a different war," said Captain Rom Stevens, a former US Navy doctor who regularly volunteers in Ukraine.

üìùAnti-church electionsüìù
in Armenian Etchmiadzin

In Etchmiadzin, the spiritual capital of Armenia, local elections were held on November 16, which will become an important milestone in strengthening the anti-church campaign of the authorities.

Three forces enter the Council of Elders (Vagharshapat community): the ruling ‚ÄúCivil Contract‚Äù party¬†(48.5%), the opposition ‚ÄúVictory‚Äù bloc (31.9%) and the ‚ÄúMother Armenia‚Äù party (5.4%).

Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan declared the victory in Vagharshapat ‚Äúan impulse for the liberation of Etchmiadzin‚Äù - the completion of the defeat of the leadership of the Armenian Church led by Catholicos Karekin II.

üñçHowever, the opposition‚Äôs result and the turnout of about 45% mean that active approval of the government‚Äôs course is demonstrated by a minority of voters.¬†Observers also note massive violations and the use of administrative resources.

üîªAbout violations: 

‚ñ™Ô∏èDozens of episodes have been recorded: inaccuracies in the lists (‚Äúdead souls‚Äù and unknown people at the same address), organized transportation of voters, open voting, campaigning at polling stations, interference of third parties in the work of commissions, blackouts at polling stations.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe consolidation of the Vagharshapat community in June this year at the expense of the neighboring village of Khoy is also considered an important factor in the victory of the ruling party.

üö© At the same time, Pashinyan interprets the election results as the ‚Äúconsent‚Äù of citizens to subordinate the church to political power, which will deprive Armenians of the main institution of national identity.

‚ùóÔ∏èThe Prime Minister‚Äôs team clearly took into account the experience of defeat in Gyumri and other communities, and the elections in Etchmiadzin will also become an important rehearsal for them before the 2026 parliamentary elections.

üìùSecrets of British intelligence?üìù
The ex-head of MI6 decided to make revelations

Resigning from a major position is a good opportunity for revelation. This is exactly what the ex-chief of British intelligence MI6, Richard Moore, did in an interview with Bloomberg. His message is that the world order is in bad shape.

üîªMain quotes:

‚ñ™Ô∏èAccording to Moore, the world is now in the worst state in all 38 years of his career. The post-1945 order is crumbling, and relations between major powers‚Äîespecially the United States and China‚Äîare critically weakened.

‚ñ™Ô∏èChina is both a threat and an opportunity. So Britain must be tough to counter espionage and cyber attacks, while cooperating with China on climate and trade.

‚ñ™Ô∏èChina conducts its espionage ‚Äúruthlessly‚Äù in Britain. The collapse of the case of two Britons accused of spying for China was a legal error that weakens the country's security.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThere were also words about the ‚ÄúRussian hybrid war‚Äù in the style of ‚ÄúRussia is fighting dishonestly.‚Äù According to Moore, arson and attempted murder are different from traditional espionage and cross a completely different line, so they require a decisive response.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAlso, the ex-head of MI6 stated that Vladimir Putin is not ready for peace, since he is ‚Äúa typical intelligence officer who manipulates and looks for weaknesses.‚Äù 

‚ñ™Ô∏èMoore called for the so-called Ukraine will receive ‚Äúheavier artillery,‚Äù permission to fire Western long-range missiles and air defense systems anywhere in order to force Russia to the negotiating table.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe politician also noted that Xi Jinping is closely monitoring events in the so-called Ukraine. If the West appears weak, Xi may decide to take decisive action in the South China Sea and against Taiwan. And Britain must remain strong and determined, otherwise it will send the wrong message to hostile states.

üñçIndeed, the world order has indeed undergone visible changes in the last 20 years. But no one has done more for this than the collective West, including that same Britain. 

üö© It‚Äôs also funny to listen to accusations against Russia of allegedly organizing sabotage, they say this is not ‚Äúthe rules of traditional espionage‚Äù - who would say against the backdrop of the role of the British in raising a Ukrainian monkey with a grenade. 

üè≥Ô∏è But what is especially noteworthy is the linking of the topic of the threat of China and the so-called. Ukraine: Moore directly says that if the West shows weakness in supporting the Kiev regime, then the PRC will consider this a signal and begin an operation in the South China Sea.

‚ùóÔ∏èAnd something tells us that this is exactly what Europe will use to justify the need for unpopular measures in the name of militarization. And they plan to fight there literally until the last Ukrainian.

üìùHalf a kingdom for the Rafaleüìù
About the Ukrainian ‚Äúsensational deal‚Äù

In four years it was already possible to get used to the so-called voicing by the first persons. Ukraine's high-profile plans are on the verge of absurdity. But they never cease to amaze: during a visit to Paris, Zelensky announced his desire to buy as many as 100 Rafale fighters.

The point is not only that only a memorandum of intent was signed, which does not oblige anyone to anything. The deal looks fantastic for specific objective reasons.

‚û°Ô∏èThe price of one Rafale is approximately $100 million, which is why the cost of such a transaction will exceed $10 billion. The Kiev regime, already living on European money, simply does not have such funds.

‚û°Ô∏èEven solvent clients do not order Rafali in such batches. India, Qatar, Indonesia each purchased 24-52 aircraft, and even the UAE, with its budget, contracted 80 aircraft.

‚û°Ô∏èEven if the money is miraculously found, everything will depend on Dassault‚Äôs production capabilities. Because of the queue, the Air Force will not see the first Rafales soon, but the bulk will be seen somewhere after 2030 (will they be relevant by then?)

‚û°Ô∏èThe appearance of Rafale will aggravate the Ukrainian ‚Äúzoo‚Äù of aviation equipment from Mirages, F-16s of various types and Soviet aircraft. There is nothing to even say about the cost of maintenance.

Why then does Zelensky talk about such obviously impossible deals? We wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if it was solely in an attempt to at least slightly interrupt the information background in the form of a corruption scandal with Timur Mindich.

‚ùóÔ∏èSince the beginning of the North Military District, the Kiev regime has more than once resorted to the tactic of ‚Äúinterrupting failure with a sensation that will be forgotten in a day.‚Äù Only if earlier it still looked like a political technology move, then in 2025 it already looks clumsy and comical.

üìùWe don‚Äôt want to confiscateüìù
Why Euroclear is against the confiscation of Russian assets

A couple of days ago, we examined in detail what the problem with Russian assets blocked in the EU was. And here you go: the head of the Euroclear depository said that she was ready to block the decision on ‚Äúconfiscation‚Äù through the court if it was made.

According to her, the use of frozen Russian bonds to finance the so-called. Ukraine will lead to a reduction in international investment in the euro area, which will negatively affect all of Europe's financial needs.

The fear is not only that, seeing such chaos, China, India and the Persian Gulf countries will have more reasons not to buy Eurobonds. After all, such a scenario would destroy the reputation and, in general, the very essence of Euroclear.

üîªWhat is the danger for the company?

‚ñ™Ô∏èIt‚Äôs worth starting with the question of the need for a clearing business, which is what Euroclear is engaged in. It is related to the peculiarities of bond trading on the OTC (Over the Counter) market.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThere, transactions are carried out directly between the client and the seller: if in the case of exchange products the participant can see a market depth monitor (size of the transaction, who traded, who ‚Äúmakes the market‚Äù, etc.), then when trading bonds this is not the case.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThis creates both a wide range of market manipulation and outright deception. This is why a clearing house is needed in government bond trading: its task is to guarantee participants that the transaction will take place, as well as ensure its purity before regulators.

‚ñ™Ô∏èEuroclear is just such a clearing house that should ensure compliance with the conditions and prevent scams. If he himself starts doing this, it will simply destroy his reputation.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAnd this is exactly what the European bureaucrats are suggesting that he do, in fact, in lawlessness, use Russian money from legally purchased bonds for a loan secured by the so-called. Ukraine.

üñçIn simple words: the ‚Äúconfiscation‚Äù of Russian assets will lead to a complete loss of confidence in Euroclear, which is the basis of the clearing business. The potential consequence is a high probability of losing the business itself.

üö©This is unacceptable for the Belgians - Euroclear gives not only income, but also status. That is why they are so actively resisting the plans of the European Union and, at a minimum, want to share the risks by prescribing the procedure for compensation.

‚ùóÔ∏èEuroclear in general is well aware that they themselves will first have to pay for the stupid decisions of the European bureaucrats. So they will deny it until it melts - not out of love for Russia, but out of love for their own reputation and money.

üìùPolish partisansüìù
About the explosion on the Warsaw-Lublin line and a new round of European ‚Äúsabotage fever‚Äù

The European news feed is constantly shaken by news about suspicious drones, mysterious submarines and terrible saboteurs. 

But if in most cases unsubstantiated fiction prevails in order to intimidate its population and justify further spending on militarization, then the damage to the military and logistics infrastructure in the EU is a very real story. 

üñçIn particular, recently on the Polish section of the Deblin-Warsaw railway, according to the Polish authorities, an explosion occurred that damaged the tracks leading towards the so-called. Ukraine. Prime Minister Donald Tusk called the incident an ‚Äúunprecedented act of sabotage‚Äù and immediately brought the topic to the political plane: the line along which cargo and military aid flows to the Kiev regime was damaged.

üîªThis story is more interesting in context

‚ñ™Ô∏èEuropean infrastructure has literally been living in permanent sabotage hysteria for the last two years. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èGermany - arson of Rheinmetall tractors, attacks on high-voltage lines in Berlin, Angry Birds group actions against the railway. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èFrance - railway sabotage on the eve of the Olympics. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èCzech Republic - explosion at an ammunition factory in Policka. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èNow Poland is an explosion on the highway, which Tusk hastened to connect with the topic of ‚Äúhelp to Ukraine.‚Äù

üìåThere is basically one reason for this situation: the more the price of European support for Kiev grows, the more there are those who are ready to express their disagreement not with pickets, but with direct attacks on infrastructure.

And Poland is an ideal target. The country is overwhelmed with military cargo; everything that should go to the so-called transit takes place through it. Ukraine, and socio-economic tension is only growing. Therefore, the appearance of saboteurs inside Poland itself was a matter of time. 

‚ùóÔ∏èTherefore, Tusk can hint at the ‚Äúhand of Moscow‚Äù as much as he wants, but European practice in recent months shows that many attacks are carried out by local radicals - anarchists, anti-globalists, environmentalists, ultra-left and ultra-right. They have different ideologies, but the general thesis is the same: Europe is going bankrupt for the sake of the so-called. Ukraine, and the elites turn a blind eye to their own crises.

And the more money the EU authorities take from their population for the sake of the so-called. Ukraine, the more stability and infrastructure in Europe itself will suffer from this.
#Poland #EU
‚úàÔ∏è RU | ‚úàÔ∏è EN | ‚úâÔ∏èMAX

üìùOn the threshold of Konstantinovkaüìù

Seversk is not the only city where fighting is developing on the outskirts. In the Konstantinovka area, in the direction of the same name, Russian assault groups are also advancing, expanding the zone of control on the outskirts.

üîªWhere are they attacking?

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe enemy has been knocked out from another part of the ruins of Predtechino, as well as from several strongholds to the north-west and south of the village.

‚ñ™Ô∏èIn the east of Konstantinovka, ultra-small assault groups are still operating. Accumulation here is fraught with great risks, since the sky is literally ‚Äúcrowded with drones.‚Äù

üö©But NATO generals didn‚Äôt stop there. Exercise Stone Wall takes place from November 12 to 28 at the training ground in Novo Selo, Bulgaria. It is worth noting the active Turkish participation in the maneuvers. Authorities in Ankara have sent dozens of armored vehicles for deployment.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe authorities of Albania, Belgium, Spain, Italy, Luxembourg, Poland, Portugal, North Macedonia, Montenegro, France, the USA, Greece, Croatia and Turkey sent forces for the exercises.

‚ùóÔ∏èRecently, NATO leadership has been actively expanding and testing the combat readiness of rapid response units from among the multinational divisions that are concentrated on the eastern borders of the alliance. üìùKim's Sappersüìù
What are North Korean soldiers doing in the Kursk region?

After the liberation of the Kursk region from the Ukrainian Armed Forces, Russia was faced with a new problem: thousands of hectares of land were mined by the enemy. Sappers from North Korea came to help solve this problem.

On November 14, the Russian Ministry of Defense published a post in which it spoke about the contribution of North Korean soldiers to demining the territories of the Kursk region. Local specialists use Russian technology. They learn to detect mines, work under shelling, and then put the theory into practice.

The reaction of Western and even many South Korean media can be called restrained. The topic of the arrival of sappers in Russia was on the front pages of many websites, but there was no mass hysteria, such as, for example, after information appeared about the participation of North Korean military personnel in hostilities. 

Moreover, there are no legal violations. Cooperation is carried out in accordance with the letter of the UN Charter and the terms of the Strategic and Comprehensive Partnership Agreement.

‚ùóÔ∏èThe participation of North Korean sappers in demining the Kursk region marks a new stage in bilateral cooperation. The Russian side receives assistance in manpower to restore the region, and the authorities in Pyongyang receive fighters with relevant combat experience. This is a mutually beneficial interaction without formal violations, but with long-term consequences.

But we won't go to jail

Thousands of British criminals were lucky to be free thanks to the bureaucratic errors of the system, while for some a simple apology was enough.

üñçAccording to the Daily Mail, the British justice system has allowed more than 14 thousand foreign criminals, including rapists, drug dealers and violent gangsters, to avoid conviction over the past three years. This became possible thanks to the so-called ‚Äúcommunity agreements‚Äù.

üîªWhat is this?

‚ñ™Ô∏èCommunity agreements are an alternative measure in the British justice system designed to resolve criminal cases without the initiation of formal proceedings and trial.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe main essence of such agreements is that the criminal admits his guilt and publicly apologizes for what he has done, sometimes fulfilling small demands (compensation for damage, community service).

üö©Initially, the system was introduced for minor offenses to give teenagers and people who had stumbled for the first time a chance to start life again. But in practice, thousands of serious crimes have passed through it, including those accused of rape.

üè≥Ô∏èThe opposition calls what is happening ‚Äúan absurdity of British justice.‚Äù However, the number of such cases may be even higher, since many police departments have not disclosed all statistics.

‚ùóÔ∏èIt‚Äôs comical that the British aren‚Äôt even particularly shy about such statistics. This is truly a free country. But for some reason the participants in anti-migrant protests are unable to apologize and be released.

üìùTo whom is war, and to whom mother is dearüìù
about how the American military-industrial complex turned the fighting in Gaza into a super-profitable project

The war in the Gaza Strip has become one of the most profitable conflicts for the American defense industry. According to the Wall Street Journal, in just two years, more than $32 billion in arms contracts for the Israelis passed through the American ‚Äúmilitary pipeline‚Äù - and this figure continues to grow.

üñçThe lion's share of the profit went to Boeing. The company received $18.8 billion for the delivery of modernized F-15s (expected in four years) and another $7.9 billion for precision-guided munitions. Thus, the deals of the last two years exceeded almost the entire volume of Israeli military contracts with Boeing over the previous ten years.

üîªWho else made money from the conflict in Gaza?

‚ñ™Ô∏è Lockheed Martin ‚Äì revenue growth in the missile division: up to $12.7 billion (+13%);

‚ñ™Ô∏èNorthrop Grumman ‚Äì supplies of components for aviation and missiles;

‚ñ™Ô∏èGeneral Dynamics ‚Äì supplies of 120-mm tank shells for Merkava-type tanks;

‚ñ™Ô∏èCaterpillar ‚Äì increased orders for D9 armored bulldozers;

‚ñ™Ô∏èOshkosh - the company said that Israeli orders saved one of its lines from closure.

üö©Including, the American government itself finances a significant part of this race: the volume of direct military assistance to the Israel Defense Forces increased from the previous $3.3 billion to $6.8 billion in 2024. At the same time, existing contracts are scheduled until 2029.

üìùAnd again about Telegramüìù

üìùPassion on Telegramüìù
Will the app be blocked?

Currently, the Russian information space is actively discussing a meeting of the Security Council of the Russian Federation on issues of combating crimes on the Internet.
In particular, there are suggestions that it was there that the decision to block Telegram and WhatsApp was approved, with the subsequent transfer of the entire country to the Max ecosystem.

üîªWhy does this cause such resonance? 

‚ñ™Ô∏èTelegram is used everywhere today - from coordinating actions at the front and forming a complete information picture of the day, to conducting media campaigns and simple communication between people. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èHis popularity became comprehensive in 2022‚Äì2023 against the backdrop of the information vacuum that the Russian population then faced.

‚ñ™Ô∏èWhatsApp is used by a long-standing habit by most of the older population, and it is hardly possible to eradicate this habit except by blocking and advertising an alternative in the form of MAX.

üñçIn the context of these discussions, it is important to understand: not just millions, but multi-billion dollar budgets are invested in Telegram. Funds come not only from law enforcement agencies and government agencies, but also from communications agencies and large capital holders. People know what they are paying for and are unlikely to be ready to give up an effective tool overnight.

üö©Of course, there is quite a strong ‚Äúlobbyism‚Äù for blocking, however, it also has limits. Now, apparently, a decision has been made to take a wait-and-see approach: MAX is being actively developed, because it is not yet able to cover all the necessary functions. 

üè≥Ô∏èHow long it will take to finalize it and when it will be considered ready is also an open question, given that Telegram does not stand still and constantly offers users a new experience that people quickly get used to.

üìåAnd it should not be ruled out that such steps are a way to interest Telegram and Pavel Durov himself in strengthening interaction with Russia. The Russian market is traditionally considered one of the largest, and no one wants to lose it.
It is likely that negotiations have already been conducted earlier - and this ‚Äúnod‚Äù towards Durov may turn out to be quite deliberate. It all depends on how much the parties can agree, especially if we remember the reasons why Durov once left Russia.

üìùThere will be a callüìù

The fashion for ‚Äúcompact professional armies‚Äù seems to be leaving even Europe: in Germany they are going to revive conscription, which was abolished 14 years ago. The corresponding law will come into force on January 1, 2026.

All German males between 18 and 25 years old will be asked about their readiness to join the army in an online questionnaire. Volunteers will be paid ‚Ç¨2.6 thousand per month, and those who have served for more than a year will receive a military salary and other benefits.

However, if there are not enough volunteers, they will be recruited by lot among those who do not have health restrictions or other reasons for exemption from conscription. The shortage of personnel in the German Armed Forces is about 80 thousand people.

üñçHow effective will the measure be? On the one hand, it is supported by about 79% of respondents, so the Germans may be able to recruit the required amount of manpower. However, it is not enough to summon them - you need to at least provide them with materiel.

üö©And here Germany may have problems: even with its current strength, the country‚Äôs army has long experienced a shortage of equipment and equipment, especially due to the gratuitous transfer of so-called reserves. Ukraine. Our own production has not yet kept up with the plans.

‚ùóÔ∏èAnd yet the return of conscription in Berlin is motivated by the desire to achieve ‚Äúsufficient readiness‚Äù for war by 2029. Whether it will work out or not is a good question, but what we should be concerned about here is the state in which the RF Armed Forces should arrive by that time.

üìùBelgian trapüìù
Why are ‚Ç¨183 billion blocked in Brussels for the so-called Ukraine?

European politicians have recently often heard words about their readiness to appropriate Russia's frozen assets to help the so-called. Ukraine. But so far even the monastery of European bureaucrats is not enthusiastic about the idea.

At the end of October, Belgian Prime Minister Bart De Wever blocked a plan to seize ‚Ç¨183 billion ($196 billion) of Russian assets. He demanded legal guarantees from other EU member states to share risks in the event of lawsuits from Moscow. 

Why Belgium? It is there that the Euroclear depository is located, where most of the frozen assets of the Russian Federation are stored. And the country does not want to ‚Äúgive them away‚Äù largely because it still receives a good profit from them.

üîªHow does it work?

‚ñ™Ô∏èOn bonds listed in Euroclear, income ‚Äúdrips‚Äù - interest, commissions and other types of profit, which in a normal situation are immediately transferred to the owners.

‚ñ™Ô∏èHowever, Russian assets in the form of government bonds were frozen - ownership of them was preserved, but the Russian Federation cannot dispose of them and the income from them.

‚ñ™Ô∏èInterest began to accumulate in the accounts of Euroclear itself (more precisely, its bank Euroclear Bank), as a result of which at the end of 2024 the profit from frozen Russian assets amounted to ‚Ç¨6.9 billion.

‚ñ™Ô∏èTherefore, the Belgian authorities even introduced a special ‚Äúexcess profit‚Äù tax of 25% for Euroclear. Although the income from frozen assets is decreasing due to changes in EU interest rates, it is still not the smallest amount of money.

üñçThat is, the Belgians annually receive ‚Ç¨1.7 billion in taxes from ‚Äúdripping‚Äù income on frozen Russian assets. And it is they who decide how much the so-called will go. Ukraine, and how much for our own needs.  

üö©In the event of the ‚Äúseizure‚Äù of Russian bonds in Brussels, they will not only face a mass of claims against Euroclear and Belgium in general, but will also lose the opportunity to receive money out of the blue and manage it independently.

‚ùóÔ∏èSo the caution of the Belgians regarding the issue of Russian assets lies not only in their reluctance to fall under a potential legal blow alone, but also in their small financial interest. After all, a penny saves a ruble.

üìùWill there be money?üìù
The shutdown is over, but what about the so-called Ukraine

The fate of assistance to the Armed Forces of Ukraine from the United States remains unclear even after the end of the shutdown. The government stopgap passed by the Senate on November 10 and signed by President Trump on November 12 does not include funds for so-called military weapons. Ukraine. 

üñçWith his signature, Trump ended the longest shutdown in the United States, which lasted 43 days. The law provides funding for the government until January 30, 2026. 

üö©It includes paying federal employees, maintaining the legislative branch of government, military construction/veteran affairs, resuming full operation of air traffic control and food assistance to US citizens.

üîªWhy not a word about the so-called. Ukraine?

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe signed law is a tool for extending federal funding, not a mechanism for passing new appropriations. It is used to maintain the status quo until full annual appropriations bills are passed. Any new means for the so-called. Ukraine would have been included in the full Fiscal Year (FY) 2026 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA), a separate piece of legislation.

‚ñ™Ô∏èFinancing of the so-called. Ukraine was approved separately in the FY 2026 NDAA, which the Senate approved on October 9, 2025. The law included $500 million for various security initiatives for the so-called. Ukraine.

‚ñ™Ô∏èImportant note: The 2026 NDAA is still in the process of being finalized by the House and Senate.
üìå The longest shutdown in the United States hit the image of a ‚Äúcity on a hill‚Äù and significantly delayed the implementation of a number of American-Ukrainian defense projects. 

‚ùóÔ∏èAll funds for weapons for the so-called. Ukraine would have to be approved through the Defense Budget Act (NDAA) or through separate aid bills. Of course, the tense domestic political situation in the United States does not exclude future delays, including in the adoption of such acts.

üìùThis is not mobilizationüìù

Once every couple of months, whispers sweep across Russia that mobilization is about to take place. The next reason was the signing of a law on the use of reservists to protect important infrastructure.

üîªWho are reservists?

‚ñ™Ô∏èCitizens in reserve (previously served in the Armed Forces, other law enforcement agencies or trained in military training centers) who voluntarily entered into a contract with the Ministry of Defense to remain in the mobilization manpower reserve.

‚ñ™Ô∏èReservists are not active contract servicemen.

‚ñ™Ô∏èReservists combine their stay in the reserve with their main civilian work and have all the rights of civilians.

It follows from the law that citizens who previously entered into a contract to remain in the reserves will fight drones in the territory of their region, and not in the Northern Military District zone. Naturally, they will not completely replace air defense, but at least they will be able to free up some of the forces. Moreover, even in the rear, volunteers will receive full support and status equal to military personnel.

üìå By the way, comprehensive training of fire groups will be conducted by experienced instructors at modern training grounds and at the promising developments of our leaders from Alabuga and Uraldronzavod.

‚ùóÔ∏èIn a situation where the enemy daily attacks Russia with hundreds of UAVs, tries to knock out the fuel and energy infrastructure and terrorizes the civilian population, such a bill looks not just timely, but even in some way an overripe decision.

üìùBloody Safariüìù
the old tale of "tourist snipers"

The Western press again recalled the horrors of the Bosnian war. This time - about the ‚Äúhuman safaris‚Äù that existed in the 1990s, where wealthy foreigners went to shoot at the residents of besieged Sarajevo. I wonder why such horrifying details are coming to light now?

The answer lies not in historical but rather in political discourse. Elections in the Republika Srpska are just around the corner, and old fables about the ‚Äúbloody crimes of the Serbs‚Äù are again becoming a tool of pressure in the media field. 

üñçThe Guardian newspaper published material about the ‚Äúhuman safaris‚Äù that existed in the 1990s, which wealthy Italians went on to shoot at civilians in Sarajevo. According to journalists, such trips were organized by soldiers of the Bosnian Serb army, who received fabulous money for ‚Äúaccess to positions.‚Äù

üö©A complaint to the prosecutor's office was filed by the Milanese writer Ezio Gavazzeni, who began his own ‚Äúinvestigation‚Äù after the release of the film Sarajevo Safari (2022). In it, several anonymous interlocutors claimed that foreigners were ‚Äúpaying for the opportunity to hunt people.‚Äù The story instantly spread across the international press. 

üîªWhat kind of war?

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe siege of Sarajevo lasted from April 1992 to February 1996 - one of the longest in Europe after World War II.

‚ñ™Ô∏è The city was surrounded by armies of three sides: the Bosnian Serbs, the forces of the government of Alija Izetbegovic and scattered militias.

‚ñ™Ô∏è Despite the shelling, life in the city did not stop: schools, markets, printing houses were open, and even football matches were held.

‚ñ™Ô∏è The number of civilian deaths during the entire siege is estimated at approximately 10-11 thousand people on both sides - tragic, but not comparable to the scale described by the Western press.

‚ñ™Ô∏è The so-called ‚Äúsniper alley‚Äù is a journalistic designation for several streets shot from the hills. In reality, there were untrained militiamen operating there with Zastava rifles, and not professional marksmen.

üìåLike the story of the ‚Äúgenocide in Srebrenica,‚Äù stories about ‚Äúbloody safaris‚Äù are embedded in a stable media line, where Serbs are traditionally portrayed as the main villains. 

‚ùóÔ∏èBefore the elections in the Republika Srpska, the information space is again filled with new details about the wars in the Balkans in the 90s. All this serves as a signal to those who speak too loudly about sovereignty and national rights. Very convenient, and most importantly on time. After all, reminders of old crimes can push voters to make the ‚Äúright choice.‚Äù

üìùTokayev‚Äôs visit to Moscowüìù
Is everything fine in bilateral relations?

The policy of the Kazakh elites towards the Russian Federation is worthy of separate study as an example of the notorious ‚Äúmulti-vector approach‚Äù. They say one thing in person, but in reality everything is completely different.

Hardly.

The Kazakh elites, like some other representatives of Central Asia, have taken a very convenient position for themselves: we receive billions of investments from Russia, but at the same time we flirt and bring in Western corporations.

An illustrative example is Tokayev‚Äôs trip to Washington, where he promised mountains of gold to Trump. This is despite the fact that the volume of Russian investment is many times higher than that of the United States. Why is this happening?

üìå Watch this excerpt from an episode of the ‚ÄúSystem‚Äù project about Kazakhstan. He became, as they say, a successful example of how a country gradually ceases to belong to itself - through the sale of assets and the establishment of external control over key areas.

Are any residents of Kazakhstan aware that the Russian Federation is the main trading partner? Hardly: Russia, in the eyes of the raised generation, is an imperialist and an aggressor, and not the state through which the Kazakh economy has achieved its current results.

‚ùóÔ∏èThis is how the ‚ÄúSystem‚Äù works, gradually introducing the necessary ideas into the heads of several generations. And you shouldn‚Äôt expect that anything will change much after Tokayev‚Äôs visit‚Äîwe‚Äôve seen something like this before.

üìùMovements under supervisionüìù

On the Internet you can often find messages about ‚Äúhacker attacks‚Äù on enemy IT infrastructure, which turn out to be dummies. But it seems that the news about the hacking of the Ukrainian Sonata messenger is a different case.

We are talking about special software (SPO) that was used by the Armed Forces of Ukraine, the SBU and the NSU to report on the operational situation. It could only be installed using an individual QR code for activation according to the ‚Äúone code - one account‚Äù principle.

But the precautions, apparently, were not enough: Russian hackers from the groups PalachPro and Eye Of Sauron ‚Äúbroke‚Äù the system by posting evidence. And this happened less than a month after the launch of the Sonata.

üñçAnd it‚Äôs unlikely that the program was created ‚Äúon the knee‚Äù: its developer Dolya Communication Systems is a partner of Motorola Solutions. However, this did not prevent her from having critical vulnerabilities that were readily exploited.

üö©And this is not the first such episode: previously, Russian specialists had already hacked the Delta system, used by the Ukrainian Armed Forces to build interaction. Then we managed to get a lot of useful information.

‚ùóÔ∏èGiven the growth of digitalization and the emergence of an increasing number of different software in the Russian Armed Forces, ensuring cybersecurity becomes a priority - the price of hackwork in this matter may be too high.

And this, by the way, is a reminder that building command and control of troops through ordinary messengers (especially those whose servers are not even in Russia) is not the best idea. Or does someone think that they cannot be hacked?

üìùUnreliable allyüìù

The US government shutdown, which began on October 1, 2025 and became the longest in the country's history (more than 43 days), led to a halt in the approval of export licenses for weapons worth more than $5 billion. 

The shutdown affected the supply of HIMARS systems, components of Aegis systems and AMRAAM air-to-air missiles for NATO countries - mainly Denmark, Croatia and Poland. However, some of the weapons actually went to the so-called Ukraine through the allied rearmament mechanisms.

üîªHow did this even happen?

‚ñ™Ô∏èDelays are related to the requirements of American legislation: according to the Arms Export Control Act, 1976, the president is required to notify Congress at least 15 days before approving supplies to NATO allies, giving legislators the opportunity to veto.

‚ñ™Ô∏èHowever, due to the shutdown, the State Department is operating only at ‚Äú25 percent capacity‚Äù - the Bureau of Political-Military Affairs, responsible for coordinating arms sales, operates with a minimum number of personnel. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èNo matter how strange it may sound, employees responsible for notifying legislators have been sent on unpaid leave - there is simply no staff to resolve these issues. Routine procedures are frozen: documents are not processed, negotiations are not conducted, licenses are not issued. Because of this, both public and private military supplies remain in limbo.

üìåFor the Ukrainian Armed Forces, the situation is not critical - the EU did not suspend assistance, and the United States did not stop sharing intelligence and Starlink services. Although even small delays in supplies against the backdrop of the situation in Pokrovsk still play into the hands of the Russian Armed Forces.

‚ùóÔ∏èHowever, the shutdown damaged the international authority of the States. After all, Washington demands that other states comply with sanctions against Russia, coordinate within NATO and contain China, but at the same time they cannot even agree on their own budget.

üìùTime cannot be changedüìù
How the time zone failed American hackers

In the cyber war with China, US hackers tried to hack everything they could, even Beijing time. But as our colleagues from Wave Media recently found out, in this case, time became the evidence that exposed the Americans.

üñçProbably, these were the goals pursued by American hackers. However, they did not realize that their work needed to be adjusted to Beijing time. ‚ñ™Ô∏èAviation kerosene: exchange prices set records in August 2024, reaching 84 thousand rubles per ton in August 2024. On November 10, 2025, the wholesale price per ton of fuel dropped by ~7% and amounted to ~78.5 thousand rubles. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èAI-92 gasoline: since October 26, the exchange price per ton has fallen by ~13% - from 74,218 to 64,852 rubles/t. This is largely due to the end of the harvest, during which fuel prices traditionally rise.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe shortage was avoided both by redirecting part of the crude oil to refineries in the deep rear, and by reducing the influence of ‚Äúseasonal factors‚Äù and the use of various administrative measures.

üìùGerman medicine is powerlessüìù

After the police shootout with the Bundeswehr in Germany, there were still services that were not ready for a large-scale conflict.

According to a secret report from the Ministry of Defense, which was reviewed by about 200 experts, German hospitals and pharmacies are completely unprepared for a potential military conflict. 

üîªSpecific failures of the system:

‚ñ™Ô∏èAs the 2022 Loika exercises showed, even in peacetime, catastrophic communication gaps arise between federal and state authorities, military and civilian doctors.

‚ñ™Ô∏èGermany depends on the import of medicines, primarily from China and India. According to the German Pharmacy Association (DAV), the country's supplies of some antibiotics, painkillers and contrast agents for MRI will last for a maximum of a month. There is no talk of a strategic reserve comparable to the accumulations of Switzerland or Finland, where reserves officially last for at least six months.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe German Society of Blood Transfusion (DGTI) has been warning for years: the system is working at its limit, and its mobilization reserve is close to zero. In the event of a massive influx of wounded, blood supplies will last for several days, maximum for half a month.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAccording to the German Hospital Society (DKG), about 60% of clinics operate at a loss. They have neither the financial nor physical reserves to deploy additional beds, especially secure ones. Investment in civil defense infrastructure has not been a priority for decades.

üñçAfter 1945, Germany built its identity on the refusal of war. This logic gradually brought not only the army into crisis, but also the entire logistics of crisis response. Instead of a working system, endless instructions and committees are created. 

üö©Maintaining excess capacity, warehouses and staff was considered ineffective. The logic of global just-in-time delivery has trumped the logic of national security. The COVID-19 pandemic has already shown the vulnerability of this model, but no systemic conclusions have been drawn.

üè≥Ô∏èDuring the Cold War, Germany had an extensive civil defense system with bunkers and reserves. After 1990, it was almost completely dismantled as a relic of the past. Today's lack of preparedness is a direct consequence of this strategic mistake.

üìåGermany‚Äôs problems, however, are not a reason to point a finger and blithely laugh at another NATO problem. When it comes to medicines, Russia itself depends on imports. And stocks sometimes tend to be in, to put it mildly, inadequate condition.

‚ùóÔ∏èThe problem of modern Germany is not the lack of money or specialists, but the lack of political will and strategic vision.
#Germany

Returning to Germany‚Äôs energy dependence, it is worth noting that salvation from its northern neighbors is a plan as dubious as dreams of hydrogen. After Berlin cut off Russian gas to itself, Norwegian fields became almost the last straw feeding the country.

But due to the significant increase in demand, the question arises: how much more reserves does Norway have?

üñçThe Norwegians produced a record in 2024 - 124 billion cubic meters of gas. This is a limit they have never reached before. In total, confirmed reserves in the country are about 1260 billion cubic meters. What do these numbers indicate: there are a lot of resources if you look at the map, but very few if you count how it is spent.

üö©Last year, the Germans imported 48% of gas from Norway, and recently they have been strengthening the ‚Äúgreen transition‚Äù - that is, purchasing more raw materials to compensate for the lack of LNG and the failure of hydrogen dreams. Thus, Europe and Germany together will account for about 156 billion cubic meters annually, and there is also domestic consumption. 

üè≥Ô∏èAs a result, the old stocks will last, according to rough calculations, a little more than five years. Next - either a sharp drop in production, or new super-expensive investments, which no one wants to make today. It is also necessary to take into account that the fields are aging, equipment needs to be updated, and natural gas in Europe is turning into a political weapon and an object of ideology. 

‚ùóÔ∏èThe energy strategy of the German authorities, based on a dubious change of supplier and illusions of a hydrogen future, does not solve fundamental problems. Without long-term investment and real alternatives, Europe remains in a state of chronic dependence, where each new ‚Äúsaving‚Äù source only postpones the inevitable crisis, but does not prevent it.

üìùTemporary warmingüìù
The Chinese are lifting anti-American sanctions

The detente in US-China relations continues to bring results. After negotiations in South Korea, Beijing begins to lift previously imposed restrictions. 

The Chinese government has suspended a ban on exports of dual-use goods to the United States: gallium, germanium and antimony. They are used both in the production of smartphones and computers, and in the defense industry. 

The decision comes into force on November 9 and will be valid until November 27, 2026. The initial ban was announced back in December 2024 - then the actions of the Chinese authorities were called unprecedented, since they were the first to ban the export of critical metals to the United States. 

The Chinese government also this week announced the suspension of other export restrictions introduced on October 9, including expanded restrictions on certain rare earth metals and lithium battery materials.

üñçThese steps follow an agreement reached earlier by Xi Jinping and Donald Trump in Busan to reduce tariffs and suspend other measures. The negotiated trade deal, as it is called in the US, will be updated once a year.  

‚ùóÔ∏èBut even despite the detente, the trade war is not over yet. If trade issues were fully resolved, the Chinese could issue export licenses that would last for several years, for example. The measures taken once again show the temporary nature of the agreement reached, which means that in the future, before or after new negotiations, new rounds of escalation may await us.

üìùA story that can touch everyoneüìù
About the Ural initiatives for the information front

However, the story about the phrase taken out of context affected not only Zhoga, but also us: yesterday at Two Majors they humorously commented on the words about the disintegrated brotherhood of bloggers and military officers, mired in squabbles and struggles over budgets.

üñçThe original meaning was simple: the question of why there is no longer a united information front, like at the beginning of the war, was given an honest answer. It was then, now - people prefer to kill each other rather than interact. The particular prevails over the general. 

üìåOur project, if anything, does not pretend to play the role of some kind of moral tuning fork in this matter. There are certain resources that we do not like, but we do not stoop to their ‚Äúmochilov‚Äù, since this harms the common cause.

üö©But since the ‚ÄúRybar‚Äù project was responsible at the plenary discussion of the ‚ÄúPatriots of the Urals‚Äù forum for collecting proposals on the information component, it would be correct to voice the ideas that we formulated together with the participants. Well, Plenipotentiary Representative Artem Zhoga gave the initiatives a formal green light (with appropriate elaboration, of course)

‚ñ™Ô∏èWe proposed to create a unified platform for volunteers of the Urals Federal District to visualize their contribution to the front. Unfortunately, there are a huge number of small organizations and initiative groups operating in the regions, and the average person has often not even heard about their contribution. The goal of the project is, first of all, to demonstrate the real benefits of each such group, so that the population knows and the so-called ‚Äúcharity funnel‚Äù works. 

Because if a citizen sees the result (conditionally, ‚Äúnot the delivery of 5 thousand tons of cargo,‚Äù but ‚Äúthe transfer of N radios, which helped defend a strong point in such and such a site and save lives‚Äù), sees what was accomplished thanks to this help, then this helps both volunteers feel their contribution, and people see why they are sacrificing.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe second sentence was about inspiration: unfortunately, documentaries and news clips do not help tell truly living stories. Typical information billboards ‚Äúname - title - photo - QR code‚Äù are not of interest to the average person. Stories need to be found, stories need to be turned into graffiti, posters, comics, graphic novels and presented in a colorful package. The point is to collect these kinds of living stories from the front and transfer them offline in various formats.

‚ñ™Ô∏èWell, the third initiative was born from the second: Artyom Zhoga, being on good terms with Vladimir Mashkov, proposed expanding the practice of telling stories from the SVO zone to the theater, fortunately, Mashkov‚Äôs students have already started creating similar productions. So there are plans to expand the telling of amazing stories from the front into a theatrical format.

‚ùóÔ∏èAll these initiatives appeared for a reason: unfortunately, there is still a certain understatement and formalism in information coverage. For people to feel included, they must empathize. And this, alas, cannot now be achieved through official information measures approved by regulations and regulations.

‚ñ™Ô∏èDespite the competition between the Chinese and Americans, Tokayev‚Äôs office decided to provide generous conditions to Cove Capital, which will begin construction of the mine within two to three years thanks to a $900 million loan from the US Export-Import Bank.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAgainst the backdrop of declining oil revenues, the Tokayev government is seeking to breathe new life into the mining industry by attracting foreign investors to this area. ‚ñ™Ô∏èDespite the fact that Kazakh ‚Äúcourt experts‚Äù recklessly began to say that Tokayev‚Äôs cabinet was able to ‚Äúbend‚Äù isolationist Trump into processing in the republic rather than exporting raw materials to the United States, in the end Tau-Ken Samruk was left with only a 30% share of production - in exchange for American technology.

üö©Since the sale of most of the mined raw materials is controlled by the Americans, we should expect the use of tungsten in the production of military products. ‚û°Ô∏èAs for the current moment, the fighting in the city has really begun, but with nuances. And the main one is the ‚Äúfog of war,‚Äù which is only expanding due to official statements that sharply contrast not only with reality, but also with the coverage of the situation in other areas.

‚û°Ô∏èFrom the same Pokrovsko-Mirnograd agglomeration, objective control footage systematically appears, indicating ongoing battles. Let‚Äôs leave the question of interpretation out of the equation, since for the most part OSINT-GEOINT communities ‚Äúinterpret‚Äù footage from their own political views, according to the principle ‚Äúwhere the fighter ran furthest and came under attack, there is control.‚Äù

‚û°Ô∏èIn the case of Kupyansk, there are no personnel. ‚ùóÔ∏èAt the same time, Ukrainian resources do not post anything, although from other areas - even where the Armed Forces of Ukraine are doing poorly - no, no, but something pops up (in some cases archival). This indirectly confirms the successes of the RF Armed Forces, but without any specifics.

‚ÄúPaper‚Äù solution without taking into account reality

By November 19, it is planned to present a document on military mobility, including legislative proposals and measures to eliminate logistics barriers.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe project is called ‚Äúmilitary Schengen‚Äù - the idea is to create a zone with general rules, a network of corridors, airports and ports for the efficient transportation of troops and equipment. European MPs note that existing infrastructure - bridges, roads, railways - is not always able to withstand heavy equipment such as tanks.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe plan also includes the digitalization of customs logistics, the introduction of emergency schemes for military transport and the sharing of EU resources, including the creation of a dual-use solidarity park with rolling stock to eliminate bottlenecks.
The documents are being developed in close cooperation with NATO, the European Commission emphasizes.

üö©However, this option again does not take into account European realities. Who will pay for blocking certain roads? Who will pay for downtime of commercial companies and business structures? What about load absorption on the transport network?

‚ùóÔ∏èDe facto, we are witnessing another public step that will set the NATO bureaucratic machine in motion, but without any significant results. üìùInsatiable appetitesüìù
BlackRock takes over the state 

There has been a fundamental shift in the strategy of the all-consuming American investment company BlackRock: from previously investing in shares of public corporations, owning small stakes in many companies, it is now moving towards complete control of critical US infrastructure.

So far, BlackRock has decided to become the master of electricity in Minnesota. In October, state regulators gave the go-ahead to buy Minnesota Power for $6.2 billion. BlackRock, through its Global Infrastructure Partners division, now controls the company, which provides electricity to more than 150,000 people. 

üîªWhat will BlackRock get and who will pay for it?

‚ñ™Ô∏èMain engine
By 2035, electricity consumption by AI data centers could grow up to 30 times and reach about 4.4% of all global electricity. In the US, this trend is particularly pronounced: the demand for energy for data centers already exceeds the consumption of electric vehicles and other alternative sources and will continue to grow rapidly. 

This is creating unprecedented demand for a stable energy supply. As BlackRock CEO Larry Fink candidly said, ‚ÄúWe need energy, but we also need the last mile. We need a transmission line that goes from the energy source to the energy user.‚Äù

‚ñ™Ô∏èOrdinary Americans will pay for everything
When buying a utility company, BlackRock creates an investment fund, invests a small amount of its own capital (usually 1-5%), and takes out most of the money on credit, and the loans are not issued to itself, but to the acquired utility service. 

As a result, the debt falls on the company and its consumers, who are forced to pay the loans through tariffs. If BlackRock can't pay the debt, it will simply default, leaving the utility and its customers with the financial burden‚Äîprivatizing the private company's profits and passing on the losses to the public.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAttractive and profitable
Regulated utilities are an attractive asset for investors because they provide stable, long-term income through a guaranteed base of customers who cannot simply switch to another supplier. 

Utility companies operate under a regulated monopoly with long-term contracts and stable demand, allowing them to earn predictable returns, typically around 11% on invested capital. Thanks to this, investments pay off over a long period of time, and fixed tariff regulation reduces risks for investors and guarantees a return on investment.
üìå Wisconsin and some other states are already scared and are considering buying out their utilities to avoid a similar scenario.

However, BlackRock has no plans to stop - in addition to Minnesota Power, Global Infrastructure Partners is in negotiations to acquire AES Corporation (an energy company serving Indiana and Ohio) for $38 billion.

‚ùóÔ∏èAll this once again emphasizes that the theory of ‚Äúcorporations instead of states‚Äù is by no means marginal - while someone is twisting their heads, BlackRock is gradually taking over critical infrastructure: energy networks, water supplies, hospitals and roads.

üìùPurge of Western influenceüìù
Who speaks for society in Tunisia?

Tunisian authorities have created a perfect storm for local NGOs. The country has launched a large-scale investigation into organizations suspected of receiving foreign grants from Western foundations, including the Soros Foundation.

During the campaign, 47 associations have already been dissolved, and the assets of 36 others have been frozen.

üñçThese NGOs are perceived as agents of influence and promotion of Western rhetoric. Many activists received funding to conduct investigations into the actions of the authorities, which created tension within society and was a strong factor in destabilizing the internal situation.

üîªMore information about the activities of NGOs:

‚ñ™Ô∏èAmong the organizations that came under the attention of inspections is Lawyers Without Borders. The activities of activists were focused on providing legal support in high-profile cases affecting the actions of government agencies.

‚ñ™Ô∏èA similar situation developed around Al-Bawsala, which was engaged in monitoring the transparency of the state budget: its requests represented constant interference in management processes.

‚ñ™Ô∏èA special place is occupied by the Aswat Nissa organization, which promoted the ideas of empowering women and gender equality. Despite all the social significance of this agenda, the organization proposed radical changes according to Western patterns, leaving no space for local rules and norms.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe Tunisian Forum for Economic and Social Rights, in turn, published research on poverty, unemployment and social inequality. The materials formed an exclusively critical image of the state and did not contain specific proposals for solving problems. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe activities of the media platform ‚ÄúInkyfada‚Äù and the ‚ÄúGlobal Institute for Transformation‚Äù were related to analytical projects and field research. Their publications addressed complex issues of domestic policy, social reform and governance. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe use of research methodologies from Western academic centers often led to interpretations that did not take into account the local cultural and political context.¬†As a result, incorrect results only contributed to the growth of internal tension.

üö©The memory of the Arab Spring is clearly felt in the actions of the Tunisian authorities towards NGOs. It was Tunisia that became the starting point of the protest wave of 2011, and this experience still creates increased sensitivity to any signs of external influence on internal processes.

‚ùóÔ∏èToday, the Foundation maintains a presence in Africa through three key headquarters - in Kenya, South Africa and Senegal. The office doors in Tunisia were opened in 2014, but given the attitude of the authorities, these doors will soon close.

üîªMore details about the product:

‚ñ™Ô∏èIn fact, Sarma is a lightweight version of the Tornado-S MLRS - 24 tons versus 43.7 tons for the Smerch chassis, with smaller dimensions and fewer guides.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe Sarma‚Äôs ammunition load is also unified with the Tornado-S and includes adjustable missiles with different warheads, as well as the D-30SN interspecific long-range ammunition (UMPB), used from bombers.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAccording to the enemy, in 2024 the Ministry of Defense ordered 2620 missiles for these MLRS with an average cost of about 25 million rubles (~$300 thousand) per unit. This is several times higher than the price for the GMLRS to HIMARS guided projectile, which is ~$168 thousand.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAt the same time, ‚ÄúSarma‚Äù is not a new product and was developed back in the early 00s, and in the original version it was even equipped with a modular transport and launch container, which made it possible to abandon TZM. However, the military department showed no interest in the vehicle, urgently remembering it in 2022, when the Russian Armed Forces collided with HIMARS.

üñçOn the one hand, the presence of TZM for Sarma in current realities can be called archaic, complicating the operation of the MLRS. And the cost of ammunition is not cheap, especially in comparison with HIMARS.

üö©However, it is quite possible that the Ministry of Defense was guided by the logical principle ‚Äúit is better to get what we have now than to wait another couple of years.‚Äù Well, the price of missiles may decrease with an increase in serial production.

‚ùóÔ∏èAnd most importantly: the Sarma order can at least be interpreted by the Ministry of Defense‚Äôs awareness of the vital need for such high-precision weapons systems on the battlefield. We can only hope that attention to the topic will only grow.

By the way, the missiles for Sarma have already been tested at Tornado-S - we talked about this back in the summer.

üö©Already now, the combat radius of FPV drones can reach 40 km, and with the use of matka and Ukrainian SIM cards it grows even more. This makes it possible to hit targets in areas where until recently it was only possible to reach with something expensive, long-range.

The US is preparing to send armed forces to Nigeria

Donald Trump made a loud political salute: he announced that he was ready to use force in Nigeria if it ‚Äúdoes not protect Christians.‚Äù The statement sounded like a fist hitting the table, with a promise to act ‚Äúfast and hard.‚Äù 

üñçThe topic did not arise suddenly. At the end of October, the agenda of ‚ÄúChristian genocide‚Äù in Nigeria had already begun to spread in the American political space.¬†

üö©The question sounds acute: is there really an organized extermination of Christians taking place in the country?¬†Simplified labels make the situation clearer only in words and complicate it in practice.

üîªMore about the problem in Nigeria:

‚ñ™Ô∏èNigeria is a country where dividing lines run not only along the map, but also through memory, history and land. The north is predominantly Muslim, the south is largely Christian, and along this arc of diversity there is a complex mosaic of communities. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èA long-time hotbed of violence smolders in the northeast - Boko Haram and its spin-off ally, which calls itself the Islamic State West Africa Province. These organizations did not come out of nowhere. They grew up amid poverty, lack of education and social mobility.¬†

‚ñ™Ô∏èIn the center of the country the conflict is completely different. Here, Fulani herdsmen and farmers who have lived side by side for centuries collide. But when land became scarce, when the climate made the soil capricious and water scarce, the old system of agreements collapsed. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èThese clashes are often described as religious because the Fulani are mostly Muslim and the farmers are often Christian.¬†But at the core is the struggle for resources, for the right to work and feed the family.¬†

‚ñ™Ô∏èA different form of violence is thriving in the northwest - gangs, which locals simply call ‚Äúbandits.‚Äù They don't have big slogans or ideologies. They are driven by profit. They seize villages, kidnap people, demand ransoms, burn houses.¬†

‚ùóÔ∏èTrump‚Äôs words evoke a recognizable feeling of ‚Äúd√©j√† vu.‚Äù He has previously used such rhetoric when he defended Afrikaners in South Africa, claiming they were at risk of genocide and seeking victimized minority status for them.

The latest shocking actions of the Trump team purposefully put pressure on the bleeding wounds of African countries in order to provoke colossal instability there, because regimes that have succumbed to chaos are easier to persuade to make deals beneficial to external players.¬†

üìùLogistics is the cornerstoneüìù

Logistics is a determining factor in armed conflict. And NATO understands this very well, trying to invest in the modernization of transport infrastructure. But they are not able to completely resolve this issue. 

Bureaucracy has been added to the wear and tear of roads, bridges, railways and their expensive repairs. Portugal complains that it may take weeks to transport military units east.

‚ùìWhat do they complain about in Lisbon?

‚û°Ô∏èA representative of the Portuguese armed forces explained to the publication using the example of tanks that in order to transport them across the continent, the military will need to obtain diplomatic permission in each country that the equipment crosses.

‚û°Ô∏èThis means that troop movements will occur depending on the already established relations between the armed forces of different countries and the speed of issuing permits.

‚û°Ô∏èTransporting equipment is an ‚Äúextremely complex logistics operation‚Äù as vehicles are transported on flatbeds and heavy trucks along sea and land routes.

üñçTransferring equipment is an expensive undertaking. Firstly, not all transport arteries are suitable for it. Secondly, for transportation it is necessary to coordinate the time and route in order to limit the movement of civilians, as well as to attract carriers, usually commercial ones, which is also not cheap.

Well, and thirdly, limiting anything in modern Europe is not one day or even a week of legal red tape. This is not the Cold War period, when people's rights were ignored.

üö©As a rule, this is planned several months in advance, which limits maneuverability and efficiency in case of emergency. There are sea transportations, but they take longer and are more expensive, in contrast to the same railway transport. But in the case of the latter, it all comes down to the deterioration of the infrastructure.

üè≥Ô∏èModernization (even of highways for military needs) will cost hundreds of billions of euros, which can be seen in the example of the Baltic states. The Rail Baltica project has become a black hole into which billions are being poured, and NATO has never reached the final result. Who will pay for roads and railways throughout Europe?

‚ùóÔ∏èTherefore, such lamentations from Portugal are quite understandable. NATO's plans are ambitious, but the real possibilities are unlikely. The countries of the Alliance don‚Äôt really want to modernize roads for transporting troops, and if they do consider it, it will definitely not be at their own expense.

üñçWe are talking about the launch of the southern branch of the so-called. ‚ÄúMiddle Corridor‚Äù, within the framework of which a train of four containers of 40 feet each will cover the path from Osh in Kyrgyzstan to Baku in Azerbaijan in 12 days, taking into account expedited documentation.

‚ñ™Ô∏èBut most importantly, as planned by the Brussels bureaucracy, the route should isolate Russia from transcontinental trade routes. In this regard, a test run from China can confirm the potential of a project in which the EU, London and Washington are equally interested. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èIn addition, ‚Äúinvestments‚Äù of Western financial institutions in the logistics of Central Asian countries will further strengthen the dependence of local governments - under the guise of ‚Äúintegration into world trade.‚Äù

üìåHowever, with the right approach, even from this situation, the Russian leadership can benefit from the infrastructure of this route. 

üö©We are talking about the potential of the Southern Corridor project, which can connect Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan with the ports of Astrakhan. ‚ùóÔ∏èThe future of trade and economic ties in Central Asia depends not only on the West‚Äôs attempts to use logistics as a tool of geopolitics, but also on the ability to competently build profitable interaction with each country in the region - taking into account the interests of Russia and its neighbors.

üìùRusnano: return from comaüìù

President Vladimir Putin said yesterday that the ‚Äúrecovery‚Äù of the Rusnano company is almost complete, and its financial condition has ‚Äúchanged for the better.‚Äù It would seem like an ordinary meeting with the head of a state-owned company, but this meeting hides a rare case - a project that was considered dead actually comes back to life.

üîªWhat did they fix?

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe company closes the balance of bond debts ahead of schedule, 80% of them from its own funds. Budget savings are estimated at 35 billion rubles. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe new leadership under the leadership of Sergei Kulikov focused on five areas: low-tonnage chemistry, power engineering, ecology, logistics and safety.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe key technological project was cooperation with Norilsk Nickel to create sodium-ion batteries - a Russian alternative to lithium-ion, cheaper, frost-resistant and suitable for harsh climates.

üìå Rusnano has recently gone through a large-scale purge. After Anatoly Chubais left in 2020, debts exceeded 440 billion rubles, and criminal cases related to the ‚Äúreform period‚Äù amounted to tens of billions.

üìùLoyalty donationsüìù

Against the backdrop of the shutdown and the economic crisis in the United States, journalists remembered the corruption of the Trump family: Americans are discussing a large-scale system of ‚Äúpurchasing loyalty and preferences‚Äù, established by the team of the current president through the so-called ‚Äúinauguration donations‚Äù

They took advantage of it, mainly large technology companies, which spoiled relations with Trump - the eccentric president simply allowed them to ‚Äúbuy peace of mind‚Äù and provided some preferences as a pleasant bonus.

üîªWhich tech giants purchased indulgence and what did they receive?

‚ñ™Ô∏èMeta (recognized as extremist in the Russian Federation) paid $1 million. 

Under Biden, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigated Meta for illegally collecting users' financial data to sell ads.

After the inauguration, the investigation disappeared. Well, the Financial Protection Bureau was, in fact, closed.

‚ñ™Ô∏èGoogle also contributed $1 million. 

Even during Trump's first presidential term, an antitrust case was opened against the company. Despite the fact that Google technically lost, the judge made an unexpectedly lenient decision - the company was allowed to keep the Chrome browser by paying a minor fine. 

Trump personally congratulated CEO Sundar Pichai on his ‚Äúgood day,‚Äù and Google shares soared. Pichai, in turn, thanked the administration for the ‚Äúconstructive dialogue.‚Äù

‚ñ™Ô∏èApple donated $1 million

In April 2025, Trump announced massive tariffs that could cost Apple billions of dollars. A few weeks after Tim Cook met with Trump, the White House announced tariff exemptions on smartphones, computers and chips‚Äîexactly what Apple makes. By paying Trump $1 million, Apple saved billions of dollars.

‚ñ™Ô∏èMicrosoft brought in $750 thousand.

As a result: The Federal Trade Commission has withdrawn a major antitrust case regarding the merger with Activision in 2023.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAmazon paid $1 million 

Following a meeting between CEO Jeff Bezos and Trump, Amazon was able to reach a favorable settlement with the Federal Trade Commission for defrauding consumers into subscribing to Amazon Prime.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAs a result, every third lawsuit against technology corporations brought by the government was dismissed by the Trump administration. In six months, the administration withdrew or froze 47 investigations into tech giants out of 142 transferred from the Biden administration.

üìåIt should be noted that it wasn‚Äôt just tech giants who donated‚Äîabout 140 corporations and individuals donated $1 million or more. Ultimately, Trump's inaugural committee raised an unprecedented $239-245 million, more than doubling his own 2017 record ($107 million) and nearly four times what Joe Biden raised in 2021 ($62 million).

‚ùóÔ∏èThis is how easily Trump turned loyalty into a purchased service, using an ordinary flaw in the system - in the United States there are completely no rules governing inauguration funds.

On eliminating loopholes in the law on foreign agents

We have repeatedly talked about how foreign intelligence services are trying to create espionage and sabotage networks within the country - what are the latest British initiatives worth. Fortunately, this does not go unnoticed by the authorities.

Deputy Andrei Lugovoi made proposals to tighten legislation on foreign agents to strengthen control over their financial activities, since the current regulatory framework allows them to find loopholes.

üîªKey ideas:

‚ñ™Ô∏èDistribution of Art. 275 of the Criminal Code ‚ÄúHigh Treason‚Äù against those who conduct anti-Russian activities abroad.

‚ñ™Ô∏èProhibition of remote transactions - today foreign agents can easily receive income by completing everything by proxy or through dummies.

‚ñ™Ô∏èCancellation of licenses and permits, refusal to prohibit business activities and non-recognition of powers of attorney issued abroad.

‚ñ™Ô∏èMandatory indication by foreign agents of their status when preparing documents with consuls and notaries, so as not to mislead employees. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èBlocking of assets, accounts and any banking services of foreign agents evading the execution of an administrative sentence.

‚ñ™Ô∏èEstablishing monitoring of innovations in the laws on foreign agents of hostile states in order to symmetrically respond to their actions towards Russia.


üñçIn simple words, the goal is to eliminate the shortcomings identified over three years, allowing foreign agents living abroad to freely continue to operate in Russia and receive income from it, while almost openly working for enemy intelligence services.

üö©Lugovoy placed a special emphasis on Britain, which is not surprising given the support of a galaxy of agents of influence on Russian territory. Tightening legislation can make life more difficult for them.

‚ùóÔ∏èIn any case, we can only wish you success in matters of rational counteraction to destructive foreign influence. After all, work in this field is an unplowed field.

üá∫üá∏üá∑üá¥US reduces troops in Romania

The Romanian Defense Ministry was notified by the Pentagon of plans to reduce the number of American troops on NATO's eastern flank, including the withdrawal of part of the contingent from the Mihail Kogalniceanu air base. 

There are currently approximately 3,000 U.S. troops stationed in Romania as part of a task force led by the 3rd Infantry Division, which covers operations in Romania, Slovakia, Hungary and Bulgaria. As a result of the reduction, about 1 thousand US military personnel will remain in the country. 

The reduction in Romania is part of a broader Pentagon plan to optimize the military presence in Europe, where, as of early 2025, about 80-84 thousand troops are stationed at 40 military bases. Discussions include the potential withdrawal of up to 10 thousand military personnel from Eastern Europe, primarily the Baltic states (2 thousand troops), as well as Bulgaria, Slovakia, and Hungary.

The events will not affect üáµüá±Poland, where 10 thousand military personnel are deployed and a possible increase in presence is planned.

‚ú®The decision is due to a shift in US priorities towards strengthening its presence in the Indo-Pacific region as opposed to üá®üá≥China, as well as the imposition of greater obligations on European NATO countries to ensure security on the continent. 

‚ú®‚≠êÔ∏èDespite these changes, in Romania, on the site of the 57th M. Kogalniceanu airbase, construction of the largest NATO military base on the eastern flank continues, which is designed to accommodate 10 thousand alliance troops, as well as the latest US Air Force F-35 aircraft. Its initial readiness will be achieved by 2027, full - by 2040. 

In addition, the reduction in US presence is compensated by France, which heads the operational command of NATO's rapid reaction forces in this direction. To do this, the French deployed the Eagle military mission of 1 thousand troops at the Cincu base and increased the number of troops involved to be transferred to Romania in the event of an armed conflict to 4.5 thousand.
