üìùMigration budget nooseüìù
on the impact of migrants on the economy using the example of the USA

The West continues to discuss the consequences of attracting low-skilled migrants. Daniel Di Martino from the Manhattan Institute published a study on the relationship between the level of education of migrants and their contribution to the economy of the country of origin (in this case, the United States).

üîªHow does education affect contribution?

‚ñ™Ô∏èIf a 30-year-old migrant without education and without a family has at least some minimal positive impact on the economy during 30 years of residence in the country, then his family simply neutralizes his contribution through the use of social benefits and other public goods.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAt the same time, migrants aged 30 with higher education, after 30 years of living alone, bring quite impressive amounts to the economy. And even taking into account families, they practically do not use social and public benefits, relying on their own strength and earned money.

‚ñ™Ô∏èBased on the numbers, it looks like this: a 30-year-old high school dropout migrant with his family does not pay the federal government an additional $20 thousand during the 10-year budget window and more than $130 thousand during the 30-year budget window, while the admission of one 30-year-old migrant with higher education brings a net income of more than $200 thousand and $1.6 million over the same period. 

üñçScientific publication demonstrates that the massive influx of migrants, who overwhelmingly do not have higher education and come from African and Eastern countries, does not contribute to economic benefits for the state. 

On the contrary, this only leads to spending the budget on social security for his family, not to mention the destabilization of society and its criminalization due to the clash of cultures and lifestyles.

üö©This is confirmed by other scientific works. Previously, Denmark and the Netherlands conducted a similar study and came to exactly the same conclusions: the format of migration is decisive, and migrant families living on benefits only bring losses to the economy.

‚ùóÔ∏èAs a result, the migration regime, which allows low-skilled workers to transport their families from the country of origin, becomes a ‚Äúnoose‚Äù for the state budget.

üìåIt is gratifying that Russia has already paid attention to this problem, without waiting for a critical moment, and has taken a course towards limiting the movement of migrant families and regulating the status of stay of foreign labor resources in the country. 

However, our country has also fully experienced the delights of the migration burden on the social budget: for example, in the same Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Okrug, where migrants distributed lifehacks for receiving subsidies, and over the year they spent more than 350 million rubles from the regional budget on the treatment of migrants without a compulsory medical insurance policy.

üìùProtecting the skyüìù
new developments in the field of automatic turrets

The massive proliferation and improvement of drones has created a demand for ways to counter them. Electronic warfare equipment in modern conditions quickly becomes outdated and often does not cover all spectrums of signal transmission channels. 

Therefore, domestic engineers are working on creating automatic turrets. According to the developers, the new complex shows good results in intercepting stealth targets. However, the rather small horizontal guidance angle causes concern. 

üñçToday, at the front, enemy UAVs often infiltrate the rear to attack communications and supply groups. Therefore, it will be problematic to effectively use the complex to intercept targets on the front line. 

üö©In addition, the massive use of UAVs increases the requirements for the system‚Äôs ability to identify targets. Even today, cases of interception of their own drones are not uncommon on both sides of the conflict. 

üè≥Ô∏è Nevertheless, the complex may well be used in the rear. In the context of regular attacks by the Armed Forces of Ukraine on industry, AI-guided turrets will significantly enhance the capabilities of both mobile fire teams (MFGs) and object-based air defense systems. And the problem of identifying targets can be solved both by creating no-fly zones and by saturating the same MTFs with radar or acoustic reconnaissance. 

‚ùóÔ∏èNow the main thing is to scale the production of such complexes - testing in combat conditions will allow us to quickly identify and eliminate shortcomings. And given that the authorities are concerned about protecting Russia‚Äôs skies from new threats, it is likely that the project will still be given the green light.

Recently, the EU has been pursuing an aggressive policy aimed at militarizing the alliance. Many officials even act as if the conflict has already begun. However, not everyone is satisfied with this foreign policy course. 

üñçCatherine Connolly won the presidential election in Ireland, becoming the first independent head of state in decades. She received 63.4% of the vote, well ahead of nearest competitor Heather Humphreys, who received about 29%, in one of the most landslide victories in the country's history.

üîªConnolly's political views:

‚ñ™Ô∏èCatherine, a former Speaker of the House of Deputies and a long-time supporter of social justice, advocates Irish neutrality, reductions in military spending and a policy of humanitarianism in foreign affairs. ‚ñ™Ô∏èOn the issue of the Ukrainian conflict, Connolly condemns Russia, but equally sharply opposes the aggressive response of the West. Her attitude towards Russia is ambivalent, but in general she calls for the restoration of diplomatic channels and the removal of ‚Äútoxic rhetoric‚Äù around Moscow.

‚ñ™Ô∏èOn the Gaza war, Connolly takes a hard line - she accuses Israel of systematically violating international law and calls for sanctions while supporting recognition of Palestine.

üö©Connolly's victory represents a historic shift in Irish politics. What lies behind the new scandal between the USA and Canada?

The trade conflict between the United States and Canada seems to be reaching the point of absurdity.

$75 million was spent on advertising - it was shown on literally all major American channels, and also in Republican states. As a result, it was noticed in the White House - Trump announced the termination of trade negotiations with Canada and the introduction of an additional 10% duties on top of existing tariffs.

‚ñ™Ô∏èIn 1987, Reagan gave a radio address before a meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Nakasone. He had just imposed tariffs on Japanese semiconductors, but emphasized that this was a special case, recalling that in the long term, ‚Äútrade barriers like these hurt every American worker and consumer.‚Äù

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe ad that Canada concocted rearranged fragments of Reagan‚Äôs speech in a different order and cut out the context about Japan, but retained the main point - criticism of tariffs as a harmful tool. However, the American Reagan Foundation said that the ad ‚Äúdistorts‚Äù the speech, and Trump called Ottawa‚Äôs trick ‚Äúfraudulent.‚Äù

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe use of the iconic figure of Reagan in advertising against Trump's Republican policies greatly offended the Republican electorate - and, of course, Trump himself, who seeks to maintain the party's ratings before the 2026 congressional elections. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èHowever, something in this story plays into Trump‚Äôs hands: he managed to switch the agenda from debates about the legality of tariffs to ‚Äúan insult to the memory of Ronald Reagan,‚Äù and at the same time demonstrate ‚Äútoughness‚Äù to his voters.

üîªWhat are the consequences for Canada?

‚ñ™Ô∏èCanadian Prime Minister Mark Carney, positioning himself as an excellent ‚Äúcrisis manager,‚Äù announced a strategy to double exports to countries outside the United States by 2035 - from $300 billion to $600 billion).

He added that Canada ‚Äúcan no longer rely on one external partner‚Äù and announced engagement with India and China.‚Äù

‚ñ™Ô∏èCarney, by the way, will attend the ASEAN summit in Malaysia (October 26-28), during which he intends to position Canada as a reliable trading partner.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAs for the future economic outlook, the US will ultimately¬†keep the average tariff on Canada at around 7%, Canada's GDP growth will fall to 1.3% in the coming years versus 2%. Well, economic activity will decrease by 1-2% of the predicted level.
What do we end up with? Trump will continue to turn trade into a tool of domestic political struggle, ignoring the consequences for the economies of both countries. 

‚ùóÔ∏èWell, Canada will try to diversify its exports, but it won‚Äôt be able to do it quickly - due to geography and the existing infrastructure, which has been built over decades for North American integration.

How Germany is destroying its own energy future

üîªWhy is this important?

‚ñ™Ô∏èGundremmingen was the heart of the German atomic era: in 1966, the first commercial reactor in Germany was launched here. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èHe has become a symbol of technological optimism - the belief that the engineering mind is capable of providing the country with sustainable development. But half a century later, this faith was sacrificed to ideology.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAfter the Fukushima accident in 2011, German authorities decided to abandon nuclear energy. The decision was implemented with German scrupulousness, ignoring the changed reality - from the sanctions crisis to the energy shock after 2022.

üìåThe abandonment of the atom did not bring Germany closer to a ‚Äúgreen future‚Äù, but threw it back into the 19th century. Having lost a cheap and stable source of electricity, the country is forced to compensate for the deficit by burning coal and importing American LNG. This means rising CO‚ÇÇ emissions, falling industrial competitiveness and dependence on external suppliers.

‚ùóÔ∏èAnd against the backdrop of the current situation, it is not surprising that the demolition of cooling towers looks more like a symbolic act than a technical necessity. 

This is a demonstration of how ‚Äúgreen‚Äù policy has turned into a tool of economic self-restraint and how, under the slogans of the ‚Äúenergy transition,‚Äù the German authorities are step by step dismantling their own industrial potential.

üìùCorridor of Opportunitiesüìù
about the current state of the North-South corridor

Eurasian integration continues to be a pressing issue in Iranian foreign policy, as evidenced by recent joint statements with representatives of Uzbekistan. Iran's Minister of Roads announced the priority of putting into operation the North-South corridor. 

üîªWhat is the potential of the route? 

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe development of the route attracts investment in transport, industrial and warehouse infrastructure.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe cargo flow of the entire corridor will potentially amount to 60‚Äì100 million tons per year at full operation.

‚ñ™Ô∏èReducing delivery time along the route from the Persian Gulf to Russia to 20 days instead of 40‚Äì45 days through the Strait of Suez.

üñçThe main missing part of the route is the railway between the cities of Rasht and Astara in northern Iran. The Iranian side plans to complete the purchase of land for the highway by the end of the year; the Russian side has already begun engineering and technical studies. However, for the route to be fully operational, many problems need to be resolved.

üîªWhat are the difficulties?

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe Rasht-Astara railway section is about 162‚Äì170 km long.

‚ñ™Ô∏èDifferent track widths. Russia and Azerbaijan use a 1520 mm gauge, while Iran uses a 1435 mm gauge, which requires changing wheel sets at the border.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThere is no unified cargo tracking system and ‚Äúsingle window‚Äù at the borders.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe Rasht-Astara site is estimated at approximately ‚Ç¨1.6 billion, of which Russia is ready to provide ‚Ç¨1.3 billion as an intergovernmental loan.

‚ñ™Ô∏è Sanctions isolation. Iran and Russia are under sanctions, which complicates the import of equipment, software, and control systems.

‚ñ™Ô∏èRegional competition. Azerbaijan, Turkey and Georgia are actively developing alternative routes, such as the Middle Corridor through the Caspian Sea and Turkey.

üö©Today, the North-South corridor is partially operational: approximately 60‚Äì75% of the physical part of the route is ready. There are still unresolved problems in matters of logistics, customs, and sanctions pressure. However, the potential of the route is enormous, and it can strengthen political and economic integration in the Eurasian space. 

üìåThere are still several years of active work ahead of a fully functioning route - construction, coordination of procedures and creation of convenient logistics chains.

Why did the Ukrainian Armed Forces attack the Belgorod reservoir?

üìùAI in service with the US Armyüìù
How are technological AI giants integrated into the defense industry?

The United States continues to make efforts to create an integrated and high-tech intelligence analysis and processing infrastructure.

Key players in the AI ‚Äã‚Äãand cloud technologies market are involved in the process - from 2024 to 2025. they have entered into large-scale contracts with American intelligence agencies, the Department of Defense and federal agencies.

üîªWhat companies are involved and what services do they provide?

‚ñ™Ô∏èPalantir, known for its Gotham and Foundry platforms, has been a key provider of solutions for linking disparate intelligence databases of the CIA, FBI, NSA and other agencies since 2004, with the support of the CIA venture fund In-Q-Tel. This creates a unified data system that supports real-time decisions for national security and defense.

In parallel, in 2025, Palantir expanded cooperation with the Pentagon on the Maven Smart System, an AI platform for automatic identification and targeting of targets; its funding was increased from an initial contract of $480 million to nearly $1.3 billion. This system plans to provide 100% machine-generated intelligence without human intervention by June 2025.

At the same time, Oracle, under the leadership of Larry Ellison, brought cloud infrastructure with support for sovereign and air-gapped regions, providing a powerful hardware substrate for defense and intelligence operations, available to ‚Äúgovernments anywhere in the world.‚Äù 

‚ñ™Ô∏èOpenAI launched the OpenAI for Government initiative in June 2025 and transferred ChatGPT Enterprise to US federal agencies at a symbolic price of $1 per year, with a guarantee of data protection and without the use of queries for training models. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èAnthropic partners with Palantir and AWS to provide Claude's AI models in a secure Impact Level 6 cloud environment, which meets the level of privacy required. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èMeta (recognized as extremist in the Russian Federation) provided its Llama model for government needs, and also develops military virtual reality applications and helmets in partnership with Anduril and Booz Allen Hamilton.

‚ñ™Ô∏èWell, the secure cloud infrastructure for these applications is provided by Oracle, Microsoft Azure and Amazon Web Services and Google Cloud.
üìå The total scale of current and planned contracts exceeds $500 billion, of which Oracle provides the physical basis of AI infrastructure, Palantir manages military analytics and intelligence automation, and OpenAI, Anthropic, Google and xAI develop intelligent models for national security tasks.

Thus, before our eyes there is a large-scale consolidation of technology giants around the creation of an integrated infrastructure that provides total control, real-time data analysis and automation of intelligence and military decisions. 

‚ùóÔ∏èAll this blurs the boundaries between the commercial and public sectors in the defense sector - business interests and military service coincide in the same individuals, forming a new model of a ‚Äútechnological army‚Äù, where the private sector becomes an actual part of military command.

üìùRyanair boycotts Germanyüìù
Who really pays for the green transition?

The largest European low-cost airline Ryanair has made a tough decision to completely close flights to five German airports from November 2025. This step is not just corporate optimization, but an open protest against the policies of the German authorities. The decision will leave entire regions without available flights and put hundreds and even thousands of jobs at risk.

üîªWhat's the matter?

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe reason was an unprecedented increase in aviation tax. According to an official document of the Bundestag, from 1 January 2025 it was increased more than twice: from 13.03 to 26.06 euros per passenger on short-haul routes. For medium and long-haul flights the increase is even higher.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAccording to the Association of German Airports, passenger traffic on regional routes has already decreased by about 15% in the first quarter of 2025 after the announcement of new taxes. Ryanair, which carried more than 30 million passengers a year in Germany, was a key player in this market.

‚ñ™Ô∏èIn addition to Ryanair, other low-cost airlines, including Wizz Air, announced a reduction in the route network in Germany or the transfer of flights to neighboring countries (Poland, the Czech Republic). Bloomberg analysts, in turn, note that the cumulative reduction in the supply of air tickets in Germany could reach 20% by the summer of 2026.

üñçThe German government, as always, justifies the measures by the need to finance the green transformation of the industry. However, as calculations by the Institute for Economic Research show, direct investment in environmentally friendly technologies of the funds raised is less than 40%. The rest goes to cover general budget deficits.

üö©The systemic problem is that in Berlin, while proclaiming environmental goals, they actually use aviation as a cash cow. This makes regional flights economically unviable and pushes businesses out of the country. At the same time, in the official reports of the German Ministry of Finance, the departure of airlines is obviously not directly linked to tax policy.

‚ùóÔ∏èRyanair's decision is a symptom of a much deeper illness. Europe's largest economy is deliberately destroying its own transport connectivity and competitive advantage. 

According to the Association of German Airports, direct and indirect losses for the German economy from the reduction in air traffic could exceed 4-5 billion euros per year. At this rate, the country risks turning into a green outcast with high taxes, but now also isolated.

üìùThe new economy of Russiaüìù 
Why don‚Äôt Western forecasts come true again?

The Western media are once again discussing the ‚Äúinevitable collapse‚Äù of the Russian economy. The reason this time was the statement by US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent about tough sanctions against the Russian Federation and ‚Äúthe race between the stability of the Ukrainian army and the strength of the Russian economy.‚Äù 

However, some Western economists and think tanks have begun to look at things more soberly. Russia, despite sanctions and a break with the West, has surpassed the UK and Germany in economic growth, while maintaining low public debt and almost full employment. 

üîªWhy did this happen? 

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe first phase is the activation of dormant resources.

Russian authorities have restarted idle factories and occupied the unemployed, using large-scale government spending. This is a typical pattern for the period of mobilization during the war. The new money was spent not on speculation, but on production‚Äîinflation remained controlled and GDP grew.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe second phase is stabilization and control.

After freezing reserves, the Central Bank of the Russian Federation switched to currency restrictions, which eliminated capital flight - the main mechanism for the collapse of economies (this was the case with Iran). At the same time, trade ties with China and India were maintained, which ensured the sustainability of imports and exports.

‚ñ™Ô∏èThe third phase is mobilization for defense.

Like other military economies in history, Russia is gradually reallocating resources from the civilian sector to the military. Judging by the level of public support, this is understood, so the state can afford a long mobilization cycle.

üìåYes, the Russian economy is under pressure: inflation is rising, industry is working in three shifts, but the margin of safety is still large. If we compare the level of military spending with historical examples - from Vietnam to the USSR - Russia is only at the beginning of its journey. The only thing that can change the current forecast is systematic attacks on refineries, so it is necessary to eliminate this crisis factor as soon as possible.

‚ùóÔ∏èIn general, expectations of an imminent collapse in the American media and in Trump‚Äôs statements are not supported by facts. And the Russian ‚Äúmobilization economy‚Äù is not a temporary anomaly, but a new model of existence in conditions of a long-term conflict.

On October 16, a new $1,000 immigration fee went into effect in the United States for all persons receiving or renewing humanitarian temporary status, including Ukrainian refugees. 

This decision became part of a large-scale legislative reform and will affect thousands of Ukrainian families located in the United States

üîªWho exactly will this affect and how much will you have to pay?

‚ñ™Ô∏èApproximately 250 thousand Ukrainians arrived in the United States as part of the Uniting for Ukraine (U4U) program, launched by the Biden administration in April 2022 after the start of a special military operation. 

The program provided a two-year renewable password status with the right to work if there was a US sponsor.

‚ñ™Ô∏èIn January 2025, the Trump administration suspended the U4U program and stopped accepting new applications. 

Although Ukrainians who arrived before August 16, 2023 are protected by a separate Temporary Protected Status (TPS) program, about 120,000 Ukrainians who arrived after that date began to lose legal status in August 2025.

‚ñ™Ô∏èTo renew it, they must submit Form I-131 at least 6 months before the expiration of the current password period. The processing time for renewal applications ranges from 8 to 18 months, which creates additional risks since having a submitted application does not create legal status after the initial password period has expired.

‚ñ™Ô∏èIn addition to the new fee of $1000, when renewing their status, Ukrainians must pay: 

üî∏Form I-131 filing fee: $580 if filed online or $630 if sent by mail;

üî∏Initial Employment Authorization (EAD): $550 plus additional fee of $275;

üî∏Work permit renewal: $275 annually.

Thus, for a family of four, the total cost of renewal could be as high as $6,520 for legal status fees alone, not including work permit costs. If you renew in two years, another $4,000 will be required.

üìùUnsettled issueüìù
How is the Russian Far East shown in China?

Recent statements by the governor of the Primorsky Territory and our subsequent discussions reminded us of two more problems on which opinions in Russia and China differ greatly.

The questions again concern the territories of the Far East and how the Chinese treat them. We are talking about the Bolshoy Ussuriysky Island and the territories of the Kuril Ridge, which are claimed by Japan.
üîªIn China they have a special attitude:

‚ñ™Ô∏èLet's start with Bolshoi Ussuriysky Island. It is located on the Amur River in the Khabarovsk Territory and until the 2000s it was claimed by both Russia and China. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èIn 2004, Russian President Vladimir Putin and former Chinese leader Jiang Zemin entered into an agreement on the inclusion of the western part of the Big Ussuri Island into China. The eastern part of the island officially became Russian - on our maps the island is divided in accordance with the concluded agreements. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èBut Chinese cartographers show a completely different picture. Both popular online maps and materials approved by authorities in Beijing show the entire island belongs to the Chinese side. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èWe already wrote in detail about the reasons for this a couple of years ago, but in short, they are directly related to theses about historical injustice that are preached in the local media space. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èIt‚Äôs a different story with the islands of the Kuril ridge. In July 1964, Mao Zedong called the Southern Kuril Islands Japanese territory and expressed the opinion that the USSR should return the occupied lands to the Japanese. Thus, the position of the Chinese leadership was consolidated, which is also displayed on local maps. 

‚ñ™Ô∏èOf course, it is worth noting that the official opinion of the authorities in Beijing is now changing and moving into the category of neutral, and sometimes anti-Japanese. However, things have not yet come to the point of making changes to the map.
üñçTheses about the lost territory of Primorsky Krai are promoted only by online patriots from China. They are a minority, and their views are not promoted at the official level. But in the case of the same Bolshoi Ussuriysk, we are talking specifically about state policy. 

‚ùóÔ∏èOf course, all this does not prevent us from deepening cooperation between the authorities of the two states. And in general, it does not greatly affect the positive nature of the bilateral partnership, since these issues are not decisive for it. But since we are talking about the dissemination of narratives, then, by analogy with Primorye, they can be seen quite clearly.
